passage:
Honolulu Railway
(1) Honolulu, Hawaii is ranked as the 10th worst site for traffic in the United States according to the U.S. News & World Report. (2) A commuter there has spent, in an average year, 49 hours in traffic. (3) While this gridlock is not as intense as it is in Los Angeles, where drivers annually deal with 81 hours in a standstill, residents are still unhappy with the situation. (4) To appease those dissatisfied travelers, the city government has started work on an elevated train line. (5) When completed in 2020, it will run for 20 miles through the island of Oahu. (6) It will pass through the city center as well as more far-off suburbs, and the trains would average 30 miles per hour. (7) That will be a large step up from the island's bus system, which is significantly slower. (8) Oahu has not had a good relationship with creating train lines. (9) The only railroad on the island currently serves as a museum exhibit rather than a commuter train. (10) The Oahu Railway and Land Company was the island's first train line, and it was not used the way commuters in New York City or London use their subway system. (11) The railroad was instead used to transport sugarcane and plantation workers. (12) Some of the plantation workers ate breakfast while they rode on those trains. (13) During World War II, the railway hit its peak, shuttling military equipment from one area of Oahu to another. (14) A tsunami destroyed the tracks and put the railway into a permanent retirement. (15) The railway became replaced by truck transport, which was quicker and more efficient. (16) Residents of Honolulu can look forward to having their own train line to boast about. (17) New Yorkers and Londoners will not be the only groups of people who can enjoy a mass transit system. (18) The addition of the train line could potentially bring more residents into the city of Honolulu. (19) As an added benefit, Honolulu could elevate its status to that of a world city if it invest in reliable public transportation.

passage:
Jean-Paul Sartre
(1) France has produced some of the world's most renowned philosophers. (2) John Locke and Jean-Jacques Rousseau, for instance, have come from France. (3) These thinkers have contemplated the nature of freedom. (4) Their ideas helped lead to the French revolution. (5) A more modern French thinker is Jean-Paul Sartre, whose ideas caught fire in Paris, he came to be recognized worldwide. (6) Sartre was an existentialist, meaning that he believed in the phrase, "Existence precedes essence." (7) This statement ran counter to the prevailing philosophy at the time, which posited that an idea must form before something exists, like how the idea of scissors came before the invention. (8) In Sartre's view, he believed that humans merely exist, and it is up to them to decide which rules to create for themselves and follow, if any. (9) These ideas are why Sartre believed that humans are masters of their own fate. (10) Sartre created many books that delved into his ideas about philosophy. (11) One of his most famous works is titled "Being and Nothingness". (12) In that book, Sartre describes a person's awareness of his or her existence, and how they deal with this situation. (13) He describes the concept of absence as complicated, noting that the idea that something is "gone" can only happen if that object once existed. (14) Sartre writes that the statement "I have no money" could only exist if a person has an idea of what "money" is. (15) Thus, to Sartre, there is no such thing as "nothing"; there is only a lack of something. (16) Sartre clarifies more of his ideas a few years back in his book Nausea. (17) In that fictional book, he writes about a historian who suddenly becomes very aware of his existence, and begins to feel a sense of nausea because of it.

(6) Sartre was an existentialist, meaning that he believed in the phrase, "Existence precedes essence." (7) This statement ran counter to the prevailing philosophy at the time, which posited that an idea must form before something exists, like how the idea of scissors came before the invention. (8) In Sartre's view, he believed that humans merely exist, and it is up to them to decide which rules to create for themselves and follow, if any. (9) These ideas are why Sartre believed that humans are masters of their own fate. (10) Sartre created many books that delved into his ideas about philosophy. (11) One of his most famous works is titled "Being and Nothingness". (12) In that book, Sartre describes a person's awareness of his or her existence, and how they deal with this situation. (13) He describes the concept of absence as complicated, noting that the idea that something is "gone" can only happen if that object once existed. (14) Sartre writes that the statement "I have no money" could only exist if a person has an idea of what "money" is. (15) Thus, to Sartre, there is no such thing as "nothing"; there is only a lack of something. (16) Sartre clarifies more of his ideas a few years back in his book Nausea. (17) In that fictional book, he writes about a historian who suddenly becomes very aware of his existence, and begins to feel a sense of nausea because of it.
question_text: Which of the following would best follow sentence 17, support the author's argument, and conclude the passage?
options: Another one of Sartre's great books is "The Age of Reason," which is a fictional piece that has some philosophical concepts.
Sartre lived to a healthy age of 74 years old, and scientists are studying the effects of deep thinking and longevity.
Jean Paul Sartre ultimately had a great effect on society, improving much about the way professors teach their students about philosophy.
Many of Sartre's ideas and books are now widely recognized throughout Europe and the world.

passage: After American slaves were "freed", many white landowners scrambled for loopholes in the wording of the constitutional amendment so they could find an excuse to keep slavery going. Many of these white landowners made black men work for them in coal mines, forcing these men to labor under conditions that some historians consider even worse than slavery. While this form of bondage occurred in the late 1800s, even in modern times, there is the idea of "wage slavery". The southern United States has several states with minimum wages much lower than the national average, and some states, such as Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama, boast no minimum wage at all. Marginalized groups, desperate for work, will toil in certain jobs despite the pitiful pay because they sometimes have few other options. The issue of pay and servitude in modern times is found outside of the United States as well. For example, the lower-class in Pakistan creates houses for wealthy landowners as a means of paying off a loan the upper-class has given them. Unfortunately, most laborers who work for these landowners are lied to their masters tell them they only need to work until the loan is paid off. However, the master intends to keep the family in servitude forever, and will never say when or whether the loan has been paid. In Dubai, slavery manages to continue as workers from Bangladesh work on the United Arab Emirates' many construction projects. These workers are told in their home country that their lives will become a paradise once they move to the Emirates, but instead, the Bangladeshis get their passports taken away once they enter the country and face deplorable working and living conditions. In a world where human rights are paramount, and even in Dubai, a city where there is so much wealth that there are gold bar dispensing machines, how is it that wages are kept so low? The simple answer is greed. In the words of one resident, "Most companies are owned by the government, so they oppose human rights laws because it will reduce their profit margins. It's in their interests that the workers are slaves."
question_text: What is the focus of the passage?
options: How, despite progress, slavery continues in various forms around the world.
Why Southern states limit their minimum wages.
How America manages to employ Pakistani workers to build their houses for almost no cost.
Solutions to the problems of poverty and wage slavery.

passage: Tardigrades, also known as water bears, are some of the toughest creatures that scientists have ever discovered. Despite sharing a name with a large mammal, water bears are microscopic creatures without backbones. Water bears get their unique name because they have tiny paws and distinctive walking style, which make the creatures resemble bears with many extra legs. Tardigrades can survive temperature extremes, whether they are tolerating extreme heat or cold. In fact, tardigrades can even survive the conditions of space. Why does this tiny creature seem practically indestructible? The main reason that water bears have such incredible endurance relates to cryptobiosis, a process that the water bear uses to slow down its metabolism, similar to how actual bears hibernate to slow their body's processes. When the water bear undergoes cryptobiosis, it can dry itself out to an extent where it retains just 3 percent of its water content. This ability, known as desiccation, lets the water bear survive extreme conditions, and it can be revived when it comes in contact with water. The most impressive aspect about desiccation is that water bears can remain dried out for many years. Bears can tolerate the cold, but not nearly to the extreme that tardigrades can. Polar bears, covered in fur and even warm while hibernating, brave arctic temperatures and have an average internal body temperature on par with that of a human. In fact, because polar bears have evolved to be so efficient at dealing with glacial temperatures, it is difficult for them to remain in a warm area for too long. While polar bears have impressive internal temperature regulation, studies of tardigrades have found that these creatures tolerate temperatures close to absolute zero, the coldest temperature possible. If scientists continue to study the tardigrade, they can potentially unlock its secrets and learn not only how it protects itself but also potentially learn how to apply those abilities to the human world and help people survive temperature extremes. New discoveries about water bears seem to come frequently. For instance, recently, one naturalist from New Jersey claims he may have found a new species of tardigrade. Water bears are unique creatures that humans could learn much from.
question_text: What is this passage mostly about?
options: How the tardigrade helps contribute to studies of modern medicine.
A special organism with distinct characteristics.
The reason that polar bears can tolerate extreme temperatures.
The difference between water bears and grizzly bears

passage: In 2010, a group of miners working in a copper and gold mine several miles from a mid-sized city in Chile found themselves stuck underground. Four years prior, in another mine near the same city, two trucks had collided with each other, causing an accident that killed two workers and trapped another 70 in the mine. Fortunately, nearby miners dug a tunnel to their compatriots and everyone else escaped mostly unscathed. The situation in 2010, however, was much more complicated. In 2010, 33 men were trapped in a cave collapse, 3 miles from their mine's entrance and about two-fifths of a mile deep. Given that situation, many Chileans feared that this cave-in was a death sentence for those workers. The mining company involved also had a long history of safety infractions, so it would not have surprised the citizens that the workers' lives were in danger. Seventeen days after the incident, the mining company dug small holes into the area where they thought the workers would be. The miners tied a message to the probe that the company sent down, informing the world that the subterranean laborers were still alive. During that time, the group tried to escape via ventilation shafts, but the ladders that would normally have been present and were required by mining regulation codes were missing. The families of the miners, understandably, took legal action against the mining company for failing to comply with all the necessary legal regulations (however, the lawsuit ended a few years later with the company escaping any penalty). The issues with attempting any rescue were manifold. For one, an improperly placed hole could cause even further damage beyond the initial collapse. Secondly, the entrance to the area where the miners were stuck was mainly accessible by a spiral staircase rather than a straight drop. The issue was compounded by the age of the mines, which were over a century old. Eventually, engineers figured that their best plan was to dig a shaft, 2 feet in diameter, excavate over 2000 feet down, and hoist the men up one by one from there. The engineers decided not to let the men know how long the rescue attempt would take (which they figured would span the duration of months), but did decide to send down a video camera to see how the miners were doing. The camera discovered the men had lost weight, as they had to stretch three days' worth of rations and spent all their time in a scorching underground tunnel. The men would constantly try to boost each other's morale, but one such figure, known to the other miners as the group's comedian, would often excuse himself to another room to weep. Eventually, after 70 days in the mine, the men were lifted out in a rescue capsule, one at a time. The foreman of the group jested that they had come from a long shift. While the men were revered as heroes, given grand tours of the world, and invited on television networks days after their rescue, many have been psychologically damaged by the incident. Some of them find comfort in hobbies such as soccer, or in their children. Others find solace in work. However they choose to cope with the trauma, their story is one that makes the strongest case for large companies to comply with basic safety measures and have routine safety checks to prevent such incidents from occurring in the future.
question_text: What does this passage mostly deal with?
options: The survival and rescue of a group of Chilean miners stuck underground in a cave-in.
A need for increasing regulations and imposing strict penalties on mining firms.
Various problems with digging a hole very deep into the ground.
Methods that South American psychologists recommend for dealing with trauma.

passage: The nation of Liberia in West Africa has had a complex history. To understand its existence as an autonomous region, it is necessary to look at several elements of the United States that were present during the early 1800s. During this time, slavery was rampant and many slaves looked to the continent of Africa as an ideal world to which they could escape and return to their homelands. When the "Back to Africa" movement gained momentum, thousands of free black men or freed slaves settled in Liberia and took vestiges of American culture with them. The capital of Liberia, Monrovia, was named after the president of the United States at the time - James Monroe. The flag's star, as well as its red and white stripes, are arranged in a way that makes them resemble the American flag. The Liberian constitution is based on American ideals, the country's first president was born in America, and the official language is English. The name "Liberia" literally translates to "Land of the Free" in Latin. Many of Liberia's issues were worsened by the rule of President William R. Tolbert in the 1970s. The president gave friends and family members cabinet positions and cut ties with several allied countries, believing that Liberia's economic independence was more important. The Tolbert administration suggested raising the price of rice bags, a move that made residents suspicious knowing that Tolbert and his political friends had rice farms and would stand to benefit. A political party sprung up in opposition to Tolbert's policies - the second major political party in a system that had been dominated by the True Whig Party since the country's inception as an independent state. A month after Tolbert ordered the opposing party to be dismantled and arrested several of its key members, he was killed by a group of rebels from the Liberian Armed Forces. Tolbert had American ancestry and the rebels were all indigenous Liberians, which was possibly another point of contention. The next leader and head of the coup, Samuel Doe, likely to have taken power after massive voter fraud, ruled for the next decade. He was Liberia's first native-born president. The United States grew leery of Doe's corrupt government and disinvested in the nation. A politician with a grudge against Doe gathered a militia in a neighboring country and killed Doe. Having lost two presidents in one decade, the nation was in turmoil. Two civil wars broke out, and many of the fighters were child soldiers, brainwashed from a young age to fight for their elders' side. The conflict was settled with a peace agreement in 2003. Like its role model from the west, Liberia, too, came to learn the dangers of political disagreement and the costs of civil war. Today, the region is run by its first woman president, a Harvard economist who negotiated deals that have slashed large chunks of the republic's debt. As in America, the ideal of hope keeps Liberia optimistic about the future.

passage: In September 2015, NASA's probes on Mars found strong evidence that the red planet may currently have liquid water, and such a discovery was a source of intense excitement. If liquid water, an ingredient necessary to life on Earth, could be found elsewhere, perhaps life may exist on another planet as well? A discovery that would prove even the existence of unicellular organisms on areas other than Earth would signify a scientific breakthrough and shatter the collective perception of the universe. If the universe is indeed infinite, allowing for an endless permutation of possibilities, then life seems guaranteed to exist. However, scientists on Earth have yet to discover extraterrestrial life. This conundrum is named the Fermi Paradox, named after a physicist who lamented the correlation between the number of planets and our lack of evidence for life in them. Fermi detailed several possibilities for why this might be. For one, perhaps this life exists, but only in the form of microscopic organisms. Another option is that we are in such a remote part of the galaxy that it would be nearly impossible to find anyone else - like looking for a drop of water in a particularly dry region. Perhaps Earth represents the first time life has ever formed in the universe, or even the last. The Fermi Paradox posits yet other explanations. passage: The United States Penitentiary in Atlanta is a heavily guarded building. As a medium-security prison, it is surrounded by razor wire fences, which lead out into an open field. A barbed wire fence flanks the open field, which is overseen by a watchtower, and all these factors work together as deterrents for criminals to prevent them from escaping. However, sometimes not even the strictest safety measures can prevent inmates from getting out. One inmate of the penitentiary managed to sneak out of prison grounds, grab a bag full of alcohol and cigarettes, and then return to prison. However, the inmate was caught because the Federal Bureau of Investigation caught him trying to sneak back into jail. Apparently, the prisoner was part of a group who had been sneaking in and out of the prison grounds for years. More than four years before this prisoner got caught, the Atlanta Police Department complained that inmates seemed to be temporarily escaping from the facility and police had previously found a car near the prison grounds that had contraband. While this story is modern, the idea behind prison escapes is not. The topic has inspired countless books and movies. One of the most famous prison escapes, which makes the recent break from the Atlanta prison seem relatively minor, is the now-legendary tale of a group of people who managed to escape Alcatraz. An island of the coast of San Francisco, Alcatraz was once a federal prison in the mid-1900s, housing famous outlaws such as Al Capone. One of the difficulties of attempting an escape from the prison was not just because of high-level security measures but also in the geography of the surrounding region. Inmates would have to swim for over a mile to reach land, doing so in an unfamiliar setting and with a short amount of time before search patrols would be sent. San Francisco fog would make navigating the cold waters difficult, and inmates who tried to escape could have injured themselves just by hitting sharp rocks. Late at night on June 11, 1962, a group of convicts created decoys of themselves and then tried to raft to mainland San Francisco. The FBI guesses that the men most likely drowned, potentially suffering from hypothermia. However, one tabloid mentions that some family members of the convicts claim to have received signed Christmas cards. Whether the escape was successful, the 1962 prison break is a mystery that contributes to the allure of Alcatraz.

options: A short history of escaping prisons
A recent and historical example of people breaking out of prison
Reasons that the security of prisons in the United States needs to be improved
Cases that the FBI has found the most difficult to solve.
